quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our wide-ranging conversation, we cover how LLMs and gen AI will impact how we build product in the coming years, what skills will matter most as AI becomes a bigger part of our lives, what companies can learn from slime mold, organizational kayfabe, the adjacent possible, strategy salons, why you should be thinking more like a gardener than a builder, plus a bunch of productivity tips, life advice, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A dense preview of the episode’s core mental models and practitioner-relevant themes (AI product shifts, organizational dynamics, and “gardener vs builder”).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Alex spent 13 years at Google where he worked on Search, DoubleClick.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Establishes Alex’s long-term, high-scale product experience across major Google surfaces, grounding later advice in real-world practice.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: He led Chrome's Open Web Platform team for eight years, led augmented reality within Google Maps, and developed a new toolkit to align company-wide strategy from the bottom up.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights concrete leadership examples and an actionable organizational methodology (“align company-wide strategy from the bottom up”).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: After a stint at Stripe as head of corporate strategy, he's currently founding a startup that aims to reimagine the web for the AI era.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Signals a forward-looking product thesis—reimagining the web for the AI era—that frames the episode’s strategic lens.

quotes.topic_title: Bits and Bobs: a reflection practice
quotes.text: Every so often, almost every day, someone will accidentally add a suggestion like add a space or something because it takes so long to load that while they're waiting, they'll tap on the screen and then it'll turn into taps on adding a comment or something.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A concrete, memorable example that underscores the scale and persistence of his single-doc capture system.

quotes.topic_title: Bits and Bobs: a reflection practice
quotes.text: And then once a week, I go through, I take a few hours and I just reflect to myself and try to find patterns and unpack and find meaning and things.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology: daily capture paired with weekly reflection to extract patterns and meaning.

quotes.topic_title: Bits and Bobs: a reflection practice
quotes.text: I did this for me. I'm happy to let other people see and peek into my weird mental process if they want, but this is 100% about my own self-reflection.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A practitioner reminder to optimize personal knowledge systems for learning, not for audience growth or distribution.

quotes.topic_title: Bits and Bobs: a reflection practice
quotes.text: In fact, it's designed a little bit to be, I allow myself to be a little bit illegible. I want people to have to work a little bit with it.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A counterintuitive stance: intentional roughness can preserve authenticity and reduce pressure to perform for readers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core practice for both growth and feature evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most was our experimentation platform where I could set up experiments easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of an effective experimentation workflow that empowers individual practitioners end-to-end.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more with advanced statistical methods that can help you shape weeks off experiment time, and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on what capabilities to prioritize to speed up experimentation and reduce analysis bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta's market-leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance alongside reporting and tracking risk.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical operating model: treat compliance as continuous monitoring integrated with risk tracking, not a periodic checklist.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific efficiency claim practitioners can apply by automating a common compliance time-sink.

quotes.topic_title: The Compendium: note system and embeddings
quotes.text: And so I have, I think let's see, I currently have 17,248 unpublished working notes.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing the scale of his note practice and how much raw material he keeps before publishing.

quotes.topic_title: The Compendium: note system and embeddings
quotes.text: And so what I do during the week is I'm taking notes very quickly in meetings, and then every day or two, I go through and I process them and put them in as working notes in The Compendium, and this is where I correct misspellings. I add just a little bit more context so that it will make sense to me if I were to read it in a year.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: An actionable workflow for turning messy meeting notes into durable, future-readable knowledge assets.

quotes.topic_title: The Compendium: note system and embeddings
quotes.text: And also, I built a feature into it that uses embeddings to find similar cards. I find similar ideas from the past.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A methodology for using embeddings to systematically surface adjacent ideas and connections across a personal knowledge base.

quotes.topic_title: The Compendium: note system and embeddings
quotes.text: And then what I do on Friday afternoons is I sit down and I go through all the notes I added that week and I just click and check the ones that still resonate with me, they still seem interesting in some way.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A simple weekly filtering ritual that converts volume into signal by selecting only what still feels meaningful after time passes.

quotes.topic_title: The Compendium: note system and embeddings
quotes.text: It is the place where I find most of my most interesting insights is by reflecting on interesting conversations from the week before.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A memorable statement emphasizing that insight often comes from structured reflection, not just consuming new information.

quotes.topic_title: Making time for deep thinking
quotes.text: Deep thinking takes time and space, and you got to create that space. The mundane, pointless bullshit will take every square inch you give it.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why protected time is necessary: shallow work expands to fill all available capacity unless you actively defend space for thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Making time for deep thinking
quotes.text: And the one day I don't take meetings is on Friday, and that's the day I read documents carefully that people had sent me or reflect. And I think to myself, what is the thing that if I had done it before the week started would've saved me tons of time and effort that week?
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable practice (meeting-free day) plus a weekly reflection prompt aimed at preventing avoidable work.

quotes.topic_title: Making time for deep thinking
quotes.text: So for example, maybe in 10 different one-on-ones with people on the team, I had to explain to them a strategic thing that we were doing or a change that we were making. And the idea and the way I framed it worked for everybody. Well, you know what? That should probably be a document, right?
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: if you repeat the same explanation successfully across many 1:1s, convert it into reusable written guidance.

quotes.topic_title: Making time for deep thinking
quotes.text: And it's like, you got to make the time. All of us are busy and we will always be busy.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A contrarian pushback on “I don’t have time,” reframing deep thinking as a deliberate choice rather than a luxury.

quotes.topic_title: How LLMs change product development
quotes.text: To me, LLMs are magical duct tape.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A sticky mental model for treating LLMs as a flexible connector that enables new product compositions rather than a perfect reasoning engine.

quotes.topic_title: How LLMs change product development
quotes.text: So much of how the industry is built presupposes the idea that software is expensive to write and cheap to run, and LLMs undermine both of these.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Highlights a foundational assumption that breaks under LLM economics, forcing teams to rethink product strategy, pricing, and architecture.

quotes.topic_title: How LLMs change product development
quotes.text: And so if you're going to do a consumer startup, it can't be based on advertising. It's just too expensive. Advertising cannot clear the inference costs even with inference costs declining.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A concrete business-model implication practitioners can apply when evaluating LLM-first consumer products.

quotes.topic_title: How LLMs change product development
quotes.text: And so how do you design your products assuming that this thing will be squishy and not fully accurate and fully work?
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Actionable product-design prompt: build UX, safeguards, and workflows that tolerate probabilistic outputs rather than assuming determinism.

quotes.topic_title: How LLMs change product development
quotes.text: But what can you now build now that you have magical duct tape?
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Reframes product development toward opportunity discovery—new capabilities unlocked by LLMs—rather than trying to make them autonomous oracles.

quotes.topic_title: Skills for PMs: curiosity and taste
quotes.text: I think in this early stage, we're in the community gardening phase, not the factory farming phase of this technology. And so I think what people need most is curiosity and play.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how to operate in early AI: prioritize exploration over optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Skills for PMs: curiosity and taste
quotes.text: If the playbook, if the cost structures have changed, the kinds of things are now possible, the playbook is wrong and we should throw it out or at least ignore it to some degree.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Contrarian guidance to stop relying on legacy best practices when underlying economics shift.

quotes.topic_title: Skills for PMs: curiosity and taste
quotes.text: One of the ways I put this is we've seen a vast reduction in the cost of distribution of information, and now we're seeing a reduction in the cost of information production. And most of it is slop. And so in this cacophony, how do you stand out? You stand out by having good taste.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A practical differentiation strategy for a world where content is cheap and abundant.

quotes.topic_title: Skills for PMs: curiosity and taste
quotes.text: Taste, one way of looking at this is differentiate from what the LLM would've written if given the same prompt.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A concrete heuristic for “taste”: measure distinctiveness against baseline AI output.

quotes.topic_title: Skills for PMs: curiosity and taste
quotes.text: Good taste is something that is individual and also compelling to others. And so find what things you say that resonate with other people and lean into that.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Actionable advice for developing taste: iterate toward what’s uniquely you and validated by audience resonance.

quotes.topic_title: WebSim and valuing weird AI-native products
quotes.text: Things that look alien and weird and yet are compelling, those are what we should be paying more attention to as opposed to take an existing playbook and slap something on it.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A contrarian product-evaluation heuristic: prioritize weird-but-compelling AI-native interactions over incremental “AI add-ons.”

quotes.topic_title: WebSim and valuing weird AI-native products
quotes.text: But basically it's like you type a URL and it invents what that website is using just AI LLMs.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of an AI-native interaction pattern that can inspire new product directions beyond traditional web creation workflows.

quotes.topic_title: WebSim and valuing weird AI-native products
quotes.text: It creates a coherent world that's coherent with the things that you have recently seen, because you can steer it directly and you can watch fascinating people.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mechanism—context across recent pages plus steering—that practitioners can look for when designing AI-native experiences.

quotes.topic_title: WebSim and valuing weird AI-native products
quotes.text: And you can get it to do, you realize as you play with it more, you can get it to do all kinds of specific things and you can steer it based on the way it uses the context of the last few pages.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: explore by iterating and steering via recent-context cues to unlock more specific, controllable outputs.

quotes.topic_title: AI as an individual amplifier, not collaboration tool
quotes.text: I think this is one of the reasons is that the question right now of, okay, everyone's talking about AI and yet nobody's doing... There's no interesting breakout success obviously other than OpenAI and Anthropic obviously. So is there any value being created? I think it's entirely possible.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Reframes the lack of visible company-level AI wins as potentially a measurement/visibility problem rather than a lack of value.

quotes.topic_title: AI as an individual amplifier, not collaboration tool
quotes.text: this is a thing that make individuals better in a way they might not want to tell their manager about. I can now do my job twice as fast. And if the organization sees that, they might go, "Wait a second. We should pay you half this much." They're like, "What if we get rid of some extra people or something?"
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Explains why AI adoption can be hidden: incentives push individuals to capture productivity gains privately.

quotes.topic_title: AI as an individual amplifier, not collaboration tool
quotes.text: And so if this stuff is magical duct tape, it's very hard to make scaled, repeatable, large scale things out of it. It's very easy to do rig the shit out of anything.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: AI excels as flexible “duct tape” for bespoke workflows, which resists standardization.

quotes.topic_title: AI as an individual amplifier, not collaboration tool
quotes.text: And so you'll see it being used in the small in a way that's almost entirely below the level of awareness of the seeing at the organization. The organization almost won't see it or sense it, and yet it could be adding significant value or just being used quite heavily.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Actionable implication for leaders: don’t rely on top-down visibility to assess AI usage or impact.

quotes.topic_title: AI as an individual amplifier, not collaboration tool
quotes.text: I talked to Claude 20 times a day. I just have long conversations with it. I have tons of projects loaded up with all kinds of contexts on different topics, and I literally could not do the job I do now without having a conversation partner like Claude.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Concrete example of high-frequency, context-rich usage as an “individual amplifier” workflow.

quotes.topic_title: How Alex uses Claude day-to-day
quotes.text: I use it to think through problems.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A simple, practitioner-oriented framing for LLMs as a daily thinking partner rather than a one-off tool.

quotes.topic_title: How Alex uses Claude day-to-day
quotes.text: It's just think of it as having a extremely well-read but slightly naive friend who is will never make you feel dumb and is willing to engage you in any particular topic you want to go down.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how to interact with LLMs to explore ideas without social or status friction.

quotes.topic_title: How Alex uses Claude day-to-day
quotes.text: Whereas if you can have that conversation, now this is not saying use it for legal advice, but it can allow you to explore through a problem domain and then later check it with experts and say, "I believe this is a coherent outcome or a thing that should happen." And they can go, "Oh yeah, that works."
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A practical workflow: use LLMs for broad exploration, then validate conclusions with scarce expert time.

quotes.topic_title: How Alex uses Claude day-to-day
quotes.text: So I use LLMs to help me. It's like getting a, it's like an electric bike for idea spaces. You can just cover so much more ground so much more quickly in them.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A vivid metaphor that captures the productivity boost of LLMs for rapid iteration and exploration.

quotes.topic_title: Organizational kayfabe and compounding misreporting
quotes.text: Kayfabe is a word that comes, I believe is a carny word that is used and applied to professional wrestling and it means a thing that everybody knows is fake and yet everybody acts like is real.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Defines the core mental model (kayfabe) for understanding how shared pretense operates inside organizations.

quotes.topic_title: Organizational kayfabe and compounding misreporting
quotes.text: So kayfabe in the small is optimism, enthusiasm. When someone says, "We're going to do this thing," you say, "Yeah, we're going to do that," even if I think this isn't going to work. If you say, "I don't think this think is going to work," everyone loses hope and it definitely doesn't work. So having a little bit of this is extremely valuable. It's the lubricant that allows organizations to believe they can do something and to attempt to do it.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Explains the counterintuitive value of limited “shared pretense” as a coordination tool that enables execution.

quotes.topic_title: Organizational kayfabe and compounding misreporting
quotes.text: This is a totally reasonable thing to do. It's a self-defensive thing to do. And it's probably the right thing for the organization too. The problem is this happens up multiple layers and it compounds. So then your layer above you does the same, and the same, and the same, and levels up you can be many orders of magnitude off of the ground truth.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Shows how small, rational status “white lies” compound into massive leadership miscalibration—an actionable warning for reporting systems.

quotes.topic_title: Organizational kayfabe and compounding misreporting
quotes.text: How can you allow disconfirming evidence to show up that doesn't kill you, that helps make you stronger? And if it all has to come in one massive moment that could ruin everything, then you aren't going to hear it. And then it will build up and build up and build up and build up into a super critical state that could shatter.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Offers a practical design goal for orgs: create safe channels for incremental bad news to prevent catastrophic “truth shocks.”

quotes.topic_title: Organizational kayfabe and compounding misreporting
quotes.text: It's really easy to get surrounded. If you are very powerful, you will find all the confirming evidence you need. And if it doesn't exist, it will be created for you without your knowledge.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A memorable caution that power distorts information flow, implying leaders must actively engineer exposure to disconfirming evidence.

quotes.topic_title: Gardening vs building: farming for miracles
quotes.text: Don't try to analyze beforehand which seed is going to turn into an oak tree. If it's super simple to plant the seeds, then plant the seeds. And if it starts growing, then keep watering it. That's it. That's the thing.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A highly actionable “cheap experiments + double down on traction” loop that deemphasizes premature analysis.

quotes.topic_title: Gardening vs building: farming for miracles
quotes.text: I'm saying I don't have to know the answer to the thing. If on a systemic basis I let these ideas and then you respond to the ones that are working that are viable, it doesn't really matter if you didn't know ahead of time which ones were going to work.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A contrarian stance: design a system that selects winners rather than requiring certainty upfront.

quotes.topic_title: Gardening vs building: farming for miracles
quotes.text: Part of the problem though is it can't possibly create more value than the effort that you put into it. And so what I look for instead are things that can be gardened, things that can grow on their own and that you can direct or maybe give a little bit of extra energy to or curate over, and is a totally different mindset for it.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Defines the “building vs gardening” framework and the key criterion: compounding systems that outgrow direct effort.

quotes.topic_title: Gardening vs building: farming for miracles
quotes.text: And if you do this properly, it looks like magic. It looks like a thing. It looks like getting lucky because what you're doing is you're farming for miracles.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Memorable articulation of the goal: systematically increase the odds of breakthrough outcomes via many small bets.

quotes.topic_title: Gardening vs building: farming for miracles
quotes.text: It's cheap to build a little open source, tinker the little thing and just put it there. And if nobody uses it, it's fine. It was fun to build. It took you three hours. It's fine. If someone does use it, then you just invest in incremental bit of unit each time that you find a signal that somebody is finding it useful and then you stop if you ever cease getting that information.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Concrete example of the method: low-cost ecosystem seed, watch for usage signals, then incrementally invest or stop.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for emergence and protecting experiments
quotes.text: I think that's the hardest part. And you have to have, typically what I would advise for PMs, my approach at Google was 70% of my effort and my team's effort should go on things that everybody acknowledges are important and useful and create value. Maybe it's boring, linear value, but some kind of value.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A concrete portfolio allocation (70/30) for balancing credibility-building execution with room for emergent bets.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for emergence and protecting experiments
quotes.text: But now once you do this, you have 30% of your extra time that you can plant all these seeds.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: Defines the explicit “protected experiments” budget that enables high-upside exploration without risking the team’s existence.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for emergence and protecting experiments
quotes.text: Instead of saying, "No, no, no, we don't have time for that. Be a little bit more productive over here," say, "Go for it. Here's my concerns. I imagine this part might not work, but this part is really cool right here."
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A practical coaching script for encouraging bottom-up experimentation while still providing guidance and risk framing.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for emergence and protecting experiments
quotes.text: Yeah, because one of the hardest parts about an acorn when you plant it is making sure a squirrel doesn't dig that fucker up. There's so many things that can destroy it, and just keeping it, allowing it some space and allowing it some time is the most important thing.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A memorable metaphor for why early-stage ideas need active protection and time to mature before evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for emergence and protecting experiments
quotes.text: If you want to get your team to do great work, there's no shortcut other than to have an extremely high-trust environment where people lean into their superpowers in a way that adds up to something greater than some of its parts.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A counterintuitive claim that “great” outcomes require trust and emergence rather than tighter planning and control.

quotes.topic_title: Seeing seeds of greatness in people
quotes.text: But this is why what I try to do is I try to see the greatness, the seeds of greatness in everything. Everyone and everything around me, I look for, I try to find and see, man, what is the most compelling part of this? And let me lean into that.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A practical mentoring/leadership lens: actively identify the strongest kernel in a person or idea and amplify it rather than fixating on flaws.

quotes.topic_title: Seeing seeds of greatness in people
quotes.text: And so one of the things I try to do when I meet with people, when I mentor them, I try with it within the first session or two, whenever I can get a hypothesis, I say, "I think your superpower is..." And I describe to them what I think I can see them being truly exceptional at.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable tactic for coaching: quickly form and share a “superpower hypothesis” to focus growth and motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Seeing seeds of greatness in people
quotes.text: when people feel very seen and they feel acknowledged for that, they now are willing, they're going to stretch farther and they're going to respond to nudging feedback even better because they know that you're not trying to tell them be different. You're trying to tell them be more, and you now the nudges will feel less like a stop energy and more like someone who gets me and can help me grow even more.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A feedback model: affirmation of strengths increases receptivity to critique by reframing it as expansion (“be more”) rather than correction (“be different”).

quotes.topic_title: Seeing seeds of greatness in people
quotes.text: I assume that everyone I talk to, everyone I talk to is interesting, has seeds of greatness in them, even if they don't recognize necessarily where they are.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A high-trust default assumption that can change how you hire, mentor, and collaborate—treating potential as ubiquitous.

quotes.topic_title: Seeing seeds of greatness in people
quotes.text: This is one of those things that you do to be a compassionate human. It's also, I believe, a way to maximize the amount of value, direct and indirect value, that's created.
quotes.speaker: Alex Komoroske
quotes.context: A dual-purpose principle: respect and compassion aren’t just moral choices—they’re also an optimization strategy for outcomes.
